repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Cinquieme Projet Routier : analyse
            de l'impact sur l'environnement

abstracts.cdata!:
Roads have a fundamental impact on the
            environment since they allow space occupation and,
            therefore, consumption of resources (among which
            environmental resources) and production of diverse economic
            activities (including their negative impact on the
            environment). A transport project, such as the Fifth Highway
            Project, has both direct and indirect consequences on the
            environment. An environmental analysis of such a project is,
            therefore, a way of introducing (and teaching about) the
            environmental issues in the transport administrations. It
            can also serve as a reference for future projects. This
            environmental analysis is the result of a mission realized
            to study the environmental impact of the Fifth Highway
            Project. The objectives of the mission were the following:
            1) to identify the existing documentation and competence
            necessary for the environmental analysis of transport
            projects in Mali, and, most importantly, to put on record
            the deficiencies; 2) to establish a first diagnosis on the
            environmental impact of the Fifth Highway Project and to
            make some recommendations for future projects; and 3) to
            immediately create a dynamic involving information sharing
            and teamwork between the different partners of these
            national and international projects.

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Fifth Highway Project in the Republic
            of Mali. The project's overall objectives were to:
            protect the existing priority road network and strengthen
            road institutions through: (i) the involvement of the local
            industry; (ii) greater efficiency in force account works;
            (iii) improved personnel management and training; (iv) local
            financing of maintenance and rehabilitation through the road
            fund; and (v) continued institutional development and
            capacity building. Bank performance was rated satisfactory.
            Borrower performance was rated deficient. There were eight
            key lessons learned from the project and they were as
            follows: (a) streamline procurement procedures; (b) assess
            the relative costs of force account versus private
            contracting and ensure adequate commitment to increase
            private participation by private enterprises in road
            maintenance and rehabilitation; (c) establish adequate and
            timely project accounts and audits; (d) design the project
            with a monitorable objective, such as a transfer of
            knowledge and expertise to the local counterparts; (e) avoid
            the project-by-project approach in the highways sector
            without a broad policy statement; (f) use Bank remedies,
            such as suspension, for Borrower compliance of covenants;
            (g) have all donors review annual programs in a sector round
            table as is done under the Transport Sector Project(TSP);
            and (h) seek borrower and stakeholder ownership prior to
            appraisal and maintain it during implementation.

docna.cdata!:
Mali - Fifth Highway Project : Credit 1629 -
            Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Mali - Fifth Highway Project :
            Credit 1629 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Highway Project will support:
            (i) maintenance of the priority road network; (ii) a growing
            involvement of the local private construction and mechanical
            industries in road maintenance operations; (iii) development
            of a more efficient capacity of force account works; (iv)
            the introduction of measures ensuring full financing of
            recurrent road maintenance costs from local sources; (v) a
            balanced allocation of resources to road investments and
            maintenance and continued institutional development of the
            road transport subsector; and (vi) increased efficiency of
            the transport industry.
